events.name: Reactive Programming Coursera Study Lunch!
events.description: The "Principles of Reactive Programming" course is running again! I though it would be fun to get together once a week and discuss the lectures over lunch, then attempt the assignments afterwards (possibly pair programming). https://www.coursera.org/course/reactive This is a follow-on for the Coursera class “Principles of Functional Programming in Scala”, which so far had more than 100’000 inscriptions over two iterations of the course, with some of the highest completion rates of any massive open online course worldwide. The aim of the second course is to teach the principles of reactive programming. Reactive programming is an emerging discipline which combines concurrency and event-based and asynchronous systems. It is essential for writing any kind of web-service or distributed system and is also at the core of many high-performance concurrent systems. Reactive programming can be seen as a natural extension of higher-order functional programming to concurrent systems that deal with distributed state by coordinating and orchestrating asynchronous data streams exchanged by actors. In this course you will discover key elements for writing reactive programs in a composable way. You will find out how to apply these building blocks in the construction of message-driven systems that are scalable and resilient.
events.location: Real Food Cafe, 110 Killiney Road S(239549), Singapore

events.name: DataScience SG Meetup - April (Nielsen)
events.description: UPDATE: Five more days to our meetup and 101 people on the waitlist. For those who've successfully RSVPed but now realise you're unable to attend, may we request for you to change your RSVP to 'No' please? Thank you! For our meetup in April we'll have speakers from Nielsen share about their recent data science endeavours. 7.15 pm: Networking (Finger food sponsored by our generous speakers =) 7.30 pm: • Speakers: Dr. Tung Whye Loon, Lim Chong Jie, Timothy Banks (Nielsen Data Science Institute/Buy Methods) • Title: Location-based Analytics for Marketing Research • Abstract: Nielsen is a leading marketing research company, over 90 years old, employing some 35,000 staff, and present around the world. This talk will cover work by the Nielsen Innovation Lab in Singapore. First we look into how satellite imagery can be used to improve sampling through the use of machine learning techniques, and then how the same techniques were applied to automate work allocations for field interviews on a major project. In closing, we’ll look at exploratory work in how location could be used to enhance the quality of outlet records and measure exposure to outdoor advertising. 8.45 pm: Closing and networking. See you there! =D
events.location: SMU School of Business, Seminar Room 2-2, 50 Stamford Road, Singapore 178899

events.name: Book Club: High Performance Websites
events.description: The weekly SingaporeJS book club is back! This time we will be reading the book High Performance Web Sites together and creating interactive exercises to go along with it. Bookclub for the 14th of April: Chapter 3, Chapter 4, Chapter 5. Michael skipped ahead and gave us a great overview of Chapters 3 and 4 at the previous meetup, so let's make sure everyone has read them plus Chapter 5. Here is the description about the book: Want your web site to display more quickly? This book presents 14 specific rules that will cut 25% to 50% off response time when users request a page. Author Steve Souders, in his job as Chief Performance Yahoo!, collected these best practices while optimizing some of the most-visited pages on the Web. Even sites that had already been highly optimized, such as Yahoo! Search and the Yahoo! Front Page, were able to benefit from these surprisingly simple performance guidelines. The rules in High Performance Web Sites explain how you can optimize the performance of the Ajax, CSS, JavaScript, Flash, and images that you've already built into your site -- adjustments that are critical for any rich web application. Other sources of information pay a lot of attention to tuning web servers, databases, and hardware, but the bulk of display time is taken up on the browser side and by the communication between server and browser. High Performance Web Sites covers every aspect of that process. Format for the book club: 1. Buy the book and read the Chapter (s) BEFORE the meetup. 2. Pick an Item from the Chapter and prepare some discussion points and/or questions. 3. Let the rest of us know which Item you picked by leaving a comment. We will be reading at Tim & Wei's residence at Tanjong Katong Road. Door opens at 6.30pm. Feel free to ask questions in the SingaporeJS gitter room: https://gitter.im/SingaporeJS/discussions See you there!
events.location: Tim & Wei's Residence, 244A Tanjong Katong Road, Singapore

events.name: April Drupal Meetup - Open Space
events.description: Open Space is a highly collaborative and self-organised meeting where the participants themselves create the agenda and make it happen on the spot. Come by this March with all your burning questions about Drupal, and have it answered during the Open Space! This month's open space is sponsored by PayPal Singapore! Agenda 7.00pm: Drinks & networking 7.30pm: Open Space (topics will be created during the session). 9.00pm: End of meetup, more networking Why Open Space? In summary, we want everyone get the most out of the short 2-hour meetup we have every month. We've got rave reviews on the past open space meetups. We encourage participants who attend the presentation meetups to come to our open space sessions for further discussions on the recent presentation topics. Past topics generated: • Effort estimates for Drupal projects • Forms submission, db manipulation, blocks theming, email • Drupal and e-commerce • How to encourage more Drupal adoption? • Define acceptable advertising for FB group • Is open space working for us? • Effective Drupal advice for startups • Coding drupal.sg • Drupal responsive theme • Drupal 8 • e-signature in Drupal • Drupal development phase: scrum / waterfall • Drupal as REST server Directions Once you reach the place, ask the security guard or concierge that you want to go to Paypal's office at Level 14. If you're lost, get in touch with Ardi @[masked]
events.location: PayPal Singapore, Millenia Tower, 1 Temasek Avenue, Level 14, Singapore 039192

events.name: Azure Ignite Workshop (2D/2H Event)
events.description: Hi all, As requested by several members, we will be having a 2 days (4 hours total) workshop (Hands-on) for anyone who wants to experience Microsoft Azure Virtual Machine configuration in the real world use. |THIS IS A 2 DAYS FREE EVENT| This event split into 2 days which will be on April 21 and April 22, 2015. Each day start from 07.00 PM to 09.00 PM . You need to join this 2 days event to complete the workshop course. |WHAT IS THE SUBJECT?| Here is the topics for this week Azure Ignite. * Creating Virtual Network so I can connect to my Virtual Machine on the cloud directly. * Creating Domain Controller Active Directory and Configuring DNS in Azure Virtual Machine. * Adding servers and join to the Active Directory Domain from your local machine or from other Virtual Machines. * Adding public Domain Name to your VM Active Directory and Web Server. * Creating a VPN/Proxy server using Azure VMs |WHO SHOULD JOIN| * Beginner Level to Intermediate Level . * Developers or IT Professionals . |PREREQUISITES| * You must Bring Your Own Laptop (BYOLAP) . * Members must already have an Azure account. If not yet, please create a free trial account prior to joining this workshop. You can go to this page for a start: Azure Account . You can use your local Debit Card or Credit Card for verification purpose when registering. * You must install Visual Studio 2015 CTP 6 before joining this workshop. You can Download from this link: Visual Studio 2015 CTP 6 . For non Windows OS users , you can prepare your own tools for developing (PHP, Ruby, Nodes.js, etc.) |EVENTS FACILITIES| * Food will be available (lite refreshments) * WiFi: FREE
events.location: Microsoft Auditorium (Singapore), One Marina Boulevard, Level 21 Auditorium, Singapore 018989

events.name: The 6th SoC Term Project Showcase (STePS)
events.description:
The School of Computing Term Project Showcase (STePS) aims to bring together all of the class-based projects and project modules in the School of Computing (SoC). It's a festive yet serious class showcase, in which students present their projects in all aspects of computer science and information systems to the respective Faculty, Industry guests, Government agencies, Sponsors and Investors for grading, to connect with potential employers and to seek opportunities for further development of their work through collaboration with Industry and Investors. Click  to see the invitation. 
Students, faculty, technology entrepreneurs and prospective students will have the opportunity to experience the innovations created by the students. TEN courses are participating in the Term Project Showcase this semester. Click on the links to see the project details:

events.name: SG Geek Girls Maker Series Talk #2 with Anna Filippova!
events.description: "The paradox of online collaboration: on open source work and why open source works" by Anna Filippova Ever wondered what open source technologies are out there and why they matter? We are so excited to have our next speaker for our SG Geek Girls Maker Series! Introducing our speaker: Anna Filippova , co-organizer of RubySG and current PhD Candidate at the National University of Singapore. Anna will be sharing with us about " The paradox of online collaboration: on open source work and why open source works ". Anna is a PhD Candidate at the National University of Singapore and co-organizer of the Singapore Ruby Meetup group. Everything she knows about computers and programming, she learned from Free and Open Source Software (FOSS) development. She is constantly trying to pay this forward. Her research looks at the social dynamics of FOSS systems, charting how projects work, and how they work through collaboration challenges. Armed with perspectives from communications and social psychology, Anna digs into conflicts to find out what makes and breaks working together online. She hopes to improve the experience of both FOSS projects and organisations that rely on remote work. You can find her work in peer reviewed academic publications like Computers in Human Behavior and CSCW proceedings. Anna has also appeared as a guest on Webuild.sg, and regularly speaks at barcamps and hackathons. Ask her how you can get involved in a project, about learning to code, or the many other ways you can become a part of the community. Special thanks to our sponsor Paypal for the venue and food~
events.location: PayPal, #14-01, Millenia Tower, 1 Temasek Avenue, Singapore

events.name: Two Haskell Talks (by Michał  and Laurence)
events.description: CλaSH - using Haskell as FPGA programming language: Many have asked the question of performance limits of Haskell. Current developments have proved that language perfect for rigorous mathematical reasoning may also be used for high-performance computing with parsers that are faster than C or Java parsers (hPDB), DSLs that allow to implement matrix operations using GPUs (accelerate-openCL), or SIMD operations on parallel multicore CPUs (repa). Even shorter response times may be achieved by implementing functions within Field Programmable Logic Arrays. I will tell about the current state of hardware design, and CλaSH - a new attempt to use modern Haskell as a medium for programming of hardware programming. The Modular Compilation of Effects: Compilers are traditionally factorised into a number of separate phases, such as parsing, type checking, code generation, et cetera. However, there is another potential axis of factorisation that has received comparatively little attention: the treatment of separate language features, such as mutable state, exceptions, function abstraction and conditionals. In this talk, I will show how we can address the issue of constructing compilers that are modular in the computational features supported by the source language. This approach builds upon both the datatypes `a la carte technique for extensible datatypes and the monad transformer approach to modular monadic semantics in novel ways. # Speakers: Michał: https://github.com/mgajda Laurence: http://uk.linkedin.com/in/laurenceday/en Note: change of venue, since there are more than 20 Ingenious Haskellers coming.
events.location: Hackerspace, 344B King George's Avenue, Singapore

events.name: DataDive: Earth Hour and HOME
events.description: Calling all socially conscious analysts, statisticians, data scientists, coders, hackers and designers! Come join us for a weekend of working with data to do good! RSVP to work alongside experts in the field to analyze, visualize, and mash-up the data from our non-profit partners. If we don't know you already, please tell us a bit more about yourself by filling in this Google form ! Non-Profit Organizations 1) Earth Hour World Wildlife Fund ’s Earth Hour is a global environmental movement with a core vision to create environmental impact by utilizing the power of the crowd. Started seven years ago, Earth Hour has grown to become the world’s largest mass participation event in history: celebrated in over 7,000 cities, across 7 continents and by hundreds of millions of people. Earth Hour recently took place around the world on 28 Mar 2015 (Sat, 8.30 - 9.30 pm). 2) Humanitarian Organisation for Migration Economics (HOME) Founded in 2004, the Humanitarian Organization for Migration Economics (HOME) serves the needs of the migrant worker community in Singapore by developing research and education on the socioeconomics of migration in Singapore and the countries of origin, providing social integration services for emigrants and immigrants, and providing humanitarian assistance for the effects of 'crisis' migration. There are more than 1.3 million documented migrant workers or more in Singapore, of which about 1.1 million are low-wage workers. HOME has provided services to more than 50,000 migrant workers through its provision of shelters, legal assistance, health education training and rehabilitative services. Special thanks to Fuji Xerox Singapore for being our venue sponsor! Schedule Friday, Apr 24th 7.15 pm: Doors open, sign-in (we're on the 4th floor!) 7.45 pm: Introduction to Non-Profit Organizations and Datasets 8.15 pm: Pitching for teams 8.30 pm: Formation of teams It's a great chance to learn about the non-profits and their data, meet the other volunteers you'll be working and talk with others from our partner causes. Plus, there will be snacks and drinks! Saturday, Apr 25th 9 am: Doors open, sign-in and breakfast 9.30 am: Brief review from Data Ambassadors, then data diving! 12.30 pm: Lunch 1 pm: Open Roundtables 6 pm: Dinner 9 pm: Everybody goes home for the night Saturday we'll start work on the data! DataDivers will choose which problems they'd like to work on and form teams around their individual questions. There will be roving DataKind project team leads who will help advise on and manage the projects throughout the day. Sunday, Apr 26th 9 am: Doors open, breakfast 12 noon: Presentations from teams to social organizations 2 pm: Another successful DataDive in the books! This is your chance to show the world what you have done with data! There is no expectation of slides or other presentation materials, simply use whatever method of conveying your work to the organizations you feel is best. This is also the chance for our non-profit partners to better understand what your team did. These presentations can be single or group work, but they can be no longer than 10 minutes each. We want to give everyone a chance to speak, and get people out at a reasonable time. Other items of note for the weekend Volunteers at all levels are welcome throughout the weekend . If you're already a pro, we're looking for some subject-area experts to help with project preparation and be resources throughout the DataDive. Unlike a hackathon, the goal is not (necessarily) to create an app, and it is not a competition. Instead, the objective is to work with teams of experts to understand a truly difficult problem through data. You could end up with a visualization, an analysis, some graphs, or even just some new datasets by the end of the event, and all of those are fantastic results! There is a Github repository setup to use for sharing code and analyses during the event . This will be our primary resource for capturing everything developed at the DataDive, so please use it for sharing and collaboration. We do not assign you to a problem . We want you to work with the problem and data you feel most passionate about, so come Friday with an open mind and be ready to learn. You do not have to stay the entire weekend to participate in the event . We hope that you will find a project you can dig into, but you are always welcome to come and go as you please. You do not have to work on the same project for the whole weekend . Again, we hope that you will find a project to work on to completion, but if at any point you feel like you want to change simply let the DataKind project team lead for your team know. We do not provide any hardware or software for you to use . We'll have the data and some services set up (hackpad, Github), but otherwise you should bring your own laptop and come ready to use whatever data tools you like. See you there!
events.location: Fuji Xerox Singapore, 80 Anson Road, Fuji Xerox Towers, S(079907)

events.name: NoSQL Cutting Through the Hype & Pervasive Analytics: Building a Data Strategy
events.description: We are lucky to have two great speakers visiting Singapore on the same day, so we have moved the April meeting date to coincide with their visit to Singapore. Matt Brandwein, Director of Product Marketing at Cloudera will be speaking on Pervasive Analytics: Building a Data Strategy • How is data driving change? • Where are the opportunities, across industries? • What is required to gain value from data? • How can you get started today? Akmal B. Chaudhri will be speaking on "Cutting through the NoSQL database hoopla and hype" Today, there are thought to be over 150 commercial and open source NoSQL database products. Often, these products are divided into four broad categories: key-value stores, column stores, document stores and graph stores. Increasingly, some products are combining several of these categories together into what are called multi-model database systems. Whilst the market for NoSQL database systems today is still very small and thought to be around 2% of the SQL market, the technology has attracted interest from organizations looking to solve new business problems. However, since it is still an emerging technology, careful consideration is required in finding the relevant developer skills and choosing the right product. This presentation will discuss these issues in greater detail. In particular, it will focus on some of the leading NoSQL database products and discuss their architectures and suitability for different problems. Akmal's Bio: Akmal B. Chaudhri is an Independent Consultant, specializing in Big Data, NoSQL and NewSQL database technologies. He has over 25 years experience in IT and has previously held roles as a developer, consultant, product strategist and technical trainer. He has worked for several blue-chip companies, such as Reuters and IBM and also the Big Data startups Hortonworks (Hadoop) and DataStax (Cassandra NoSQL Database). He has worked extensively on worldwide developer relations programs at IBM and worldwide university relations and academic initiative programs at Informix and IBM. He has regularly presented at many international conferences and served on the program committees for a number of major conferences and workshops. He has published and presented widely on Java, XML and Database systems and edited or co-edited 10 books. He holds a BSc (1st Class Hons.) in Computing and Information Systems, MSc in Business Systems Analysis and Design and a PhD in Computer Science. He is a Member of the British Computer Society (MBCS) and a Chartered IT Professional (CITP). Website: about.me/akmalchaudhri Twitter: @akmalchaudhri
events.location: Paypal, #14-01, 1 Temasek Boulevard, Singapore 039192

events.name: April Meetup
events.description: Hi folks! We look forward to having you join us for our April meetup, on the 28th, 7.00pm at NDC (Level 2). We're still looking for speakers! Ping us (Anna or Winston) if you'd like to do a 10-15min talk or 5 Random Ruby Tips. We're also counting down to RDRC - Early bird tickets are now on sale :) Have you bought yours? See you on the 28th! Venue: IDA Labs Level 2 @ National Design Centre, 111 Middle Road, #02-04, 188969, Singapore -------------- 1. "Open 'sesame' - The dangers of open-uri and remote code execution" Ted Johansson / @drenmi 2. 3. "5 Random Ruby Tips" Grzegorz Witek / @arnvald * Hot Picks - This is a 5-10 minute session during which anyone can stand up and say something interesting! -------------- Would you like to speak at our future meetups? You could share about your startup technology stack, your new RubyGem, or your opinions on best practices, so that people can get to know how awesome you are! We also have a 5min section on "5 Random Ruby Tips" that you can volunteer for - I am sure you must have came across some interesting Ruby nuggets in the last month right? So don't be shy! Step forward and share your knowledge! Ping Winston @winstonyw or winstonyw@gmail.com, or Anna @anna_fil or annafil@gmail.com. See you all soon! -------------- Job Postings -------------- Are you looking for Rubyists? Do you have a job posting? Email us a blurb (< 50 words) + link and we'll put it here. 1. CareerFoundry CareerFoundry.com teaches online, mentored courses in Full-Stack Web Development. We are looking to hire experienced and passionate web developers all over the world to join our mentor community. As a mentor, you'll help define the next generation of tech talent by guiding students on their path to become full-stack web developers. For more details about mentoring and to apply, please visit www.careerfoundry.com/me­ntoring. Contact: Blake Farha, Mentor Advisor blake@careerfoundry­.com 2. ReferralCandy Hi! We're looking for Full Stack Software Engineers to grow the product team! Join us to work on challenging problems in a flexible result-oriented environment. You'll be joining a small team that cares about people and stuff we do, and have the opportunity to improve daily workflows and lead feature development. See you soon! http://www.referralcandy.com/jobs -------------- Thank You, Sponsors! Food and Drinks: Venue:
events.location: IDA Labs Level 2 @ National Design Centre, 111 Middle Road, #02-04, Singapore 188969

events.name: EdTech Meetup #1 - EdTech Ecosystem Panel & Video for Better Edu. Outcomes
events.description:
Come join and network with the local EdTech community for EdTech Asia’s innaugural and free event. The evening will feature a 20 minute presentation titled Leveraging VIdeo for Better Educational Outcomes followed by a 40 minute panel discussion on Local and Regional EdTech Ecosystems: Challenges and Opportunities. Ample time for networking will be provided. 
Panelists: 
Elisha Tan is an Ecosystem Builder at Tech in Asia. She helps build startup ecosystems in Asia by providing the right resources and opportunities to founders, investors, accelerators and incubators. Prior to working at TIA, Elisha foudned Learnemy, an online marketplace where you can take in-person classes from local experts in Singapore.  Adrian Lim is the Deputy Director at IDA of Singapore where he leads a dynamic team to look at how we can work with the Education Technology industries to develop innovative and new ideas and applications in schools to enhance learning and teaching in the 21st century. Leslie Loh is active in the education startup investment space within the Asian region. He is also the founder of Tien Academy, a blended MOOC model to deliver entrepreneurship training in Singapore and across the region and acting Chairman of Lithan Education, a cooperative education provider for professional communities in Asia through competency based education and work integrated experiential learning.
events.location: Red Dot Ventures Incubation Office, , Block 79 Ayer Rajar Crescent, #04 - 03-04, Singapore 579723

It’s time to come in the light and embrace Single Page Applications. In this hour-long talk Shawn Wildermuth will walk you through creating a web app using AngularJS from scratch using ASP.NET. About Shawn: Shawn Wildermuth is an thirteen-time Microsoft MVP (ASP.NET/IIS), the author of eight books and dozens of articles on software development, and a Pluralsight author with fifteen courses to his name. He is one of the Wilder Minds ( http://wilderminds.com ) and can be reached at his blog at http://wildermuth.com Azure Session Entertainment, Trading, Private Equity domains on Azure Cloud (Lessons Learnt from a Real World Project) By Sakthis Kumar About Sakthis Kumar: - Globally spanned 15+ yrs of career in Systems Solutions, Infra Architecture, Information Security and Networks - ISPs, Financial Services, ITES, Logistics Business Domains - Certified Novell Administrator / Engineer since 1997 - Microsoft Certified Professional / Systems Engineer since 1999 - Cisco Certified Network Engineer since 2001 - Qualified Information Security Professional since 2011

events.description: Paper #1 - Predicting the NFL Using Twitter (http://arxiv.org/pdf/1310.6998v1.pdf) - Abel Molina Paper #2 - QuickCheck: A Lightweight Tool for Random Testing of Haskell Programs (http://www.eecs.northwestern.edu/~robby/courses/395-495-2009-fall/quick.pdf) - Lucas Bradstreet ------------------- What was the last paper within the realm of computing/technology you read and loved? What did it inspire you to build or tinker with? Come share the ideas in an awesome academic/research paper with fellow engineers, programmers, and paper-readers. events.name: Canonical’s 2015 OpenStack Roadshow - Singapore
events.description:
At this roadshow event, Mark Shuttleworth and the senior architects of Canonical's Openstack strategy will present the product roadmap and exchange views with cloud architects and executive sponsors for private cloud initiatives across the enterprise landscape, globally. The tour has already passed through North and South America, Europe and is now coming to Asia. It is open by invitation to those shaping private cloud strategy in select companies. 
  
Join us if Openstack is a real goal in your next 12 months. Topics will include: 

Software-defined network (SDN) evaluation strategies
Use of OpenStack for Network Function Virtualisation and other telco use cases
Security considerations for banking and other regulated industries
Scale-out storage options like Ceph and Lustre
Integration with existing infrastructure such as SANs and VMware
The intersection of industrial HPC and Openstack
Hyperdense hosting with KVM virtual machines and LXD system containers

 
  
Schedule: 10.00am: Coffee and registration  
10.30am: Presentations commence 
12.30am: Presentations end 
 Sign up to the Singapore event here or check out the full list of roadshow locations.
events.location: Marina Bay Sands Singapore, , 10 Bayfront Ave, Singapore 018956

events.name: AWS First Tuesday - May Meet up
events.description: After a successful SG User Group meetup in April, I'm pleased to announce that we will be holding an 'AWS - First Tuesday' User Group meetup on 5th May 2015 here in the AWS Singapore office. Expect a similar format, new speakers, new features - and with more Pizza this time! We'll also start a little earlier with Pizza from 7pm. WHAT: 7.00 pm - Pizza and refreshments 7.30 pm - Chris Hampartsoumian, AWS Welcome, new features since the last meet up (there's been lots!) 7.45 pm - CTO of RedMart.com, Rajesh Lingappa has agreed to come and tell us about their story. A must see. 8.00 pm - More AWS Use cases, to be posted here. Let me know if you have a technology story you would like to share with the User Group. 15 minute slots available. 8.30pm - Chris Hampartsoumian - closing remarks & upcoming events. As an AWS User, if you'd like to register for the free IoT Hack Day on May 18th, registration is at: http://aws.amazon.com/summits/singapore/hackday/ WHERE: The AWS Singapore office. https://goo.gl/maps/UzzR2 WHO CAN ATTEND: All are welcome! No prior experience needed. • Anyone who wants to know more about cloud computing and startup companies • Anyone who wants to understand the benefits of cloud computing and how to use the “cloud” to benefit their organization. • Startup founders and aspiring founders COST: Free! Snacks will be served!
events.location: AWS Offices Singapore, 23 Church Street, Capital Square, #10-01, Singapore - 049481, +65-67220300

events.name: More with LeSS: And Introduction to Large-Scale Scrum
events.description:
LeSS is a lightweight (agile) framework for scaling Scrum to more than one team. It was extracted out of the experiences of Bas Vodde and Craig Larman while Scaling Agile development in many different types of companies, products and industries over the last ten years. There are several case studies available and an upcoming book describing LeSS in detail. 
LeSS consists of the LeSS Principles, the Framework, the Guides and a set of experiments. The LeSS framework is divided into two frameworks: basic LeSS for 2-8 teams and LeSS Huge for 8+ teams. All of these are also available on the less.works website. 
LeSS is different with other scaling frameworks in the sense that it provides a very minimalistic framework that enables empiricism on a large-scale which enables the teams and organization to inspect-adapt their implementation based on their experiences and context. LeSS is based on the idea that providing too much rules, roles, artifacts and asking the organization to tailor it down is a fundamentally flawed approach and instead scaling frameworks should be minimalistic and allowing organizations to fill them in.
events.location: Goodland Building, , 18 Roberts Lane #05-01, Singapore 218297

events.name: ArtScience Late
events.description: One Thursday a month, 7pm to 10pm PV868 By TeZ 8pm and 9pm Expression Gallery, Level 4 Set your mind free through PV868, an experimental audio-visual performance created by 2015 Art/Science Resident artist, TeZ. Experience the hypnotic effects of moving visual patterns, emerging directly from the interaction of the brainwaves with the sound and light stimulation, unique to each individual. Entry is complimentary and on a first come first served basis. DISCLAIMER: PV868 performance is based on the use of flickering video light which might cause seizures in people suffering of photogenic or photosensitive epilepsy. You should not attend this show if you are already aware of being epileptic and, in any case, the artist cannot be considered responsible of the effects produced by the audio-visual stimulus of this performance. In no case will #TeZ (aka Maurizio Martinucci) or the organizers of this event be liable for chance, accidental, special, direct or indirect damages or undesired effects resulting from partaking the experience of this show.

events.name: Nurturing Leonardos
events.description: Nurturing Leonardos An international conference Friday 8 and Saturday 9 May 2015 Expression Gallery, Level 4 FREE *There will be no pre-registration for the event. Attendees may sign in when they arrive and seats will be filled on a first-come-first-served basis. On 8 and 9 May 2015, ArtScience Museum will host a conference exploring the legacy of history's most celebrated artist and scientist, Leonardo da Vinci (1452-1519). Most studies of da Vinci focus on a specific area of his activity - art, anatomy, technology, studies on water, on flight, and so on. This conference will offer a different point of view, encouraging an exploration of da Vinci's way of thinking and of the cultural landscape, which nurtured him. It will analyze how his interdisciplinary approach, which we now refer to as “systems thinking” and "complexity", remains strikingly resonant for us today, and applied within the fields of art, science, technology, architecture and foresight. The conference begins with a special edition of ArtScience Museum's monthly performance programme, ArtScience late (Thursday 7 May), and continues for two full days of discussions on 8-9 May, featuring presentations from within Singapore and around the world, from a range of leading speakers in the fields of science, history, technology, and architecture. The conference chairs are Honor Harger (ArtScience Museum) and Andrea Nanetti (Nanyang Technological University, School of Art, Design and Media and Complexity Institute). Thursday 7 May 2015 7.00 - 10.00pm: ArtScience Late with a special performance from TeZ, our international ArtScience resident. Friday 8 May 2015 10:00am - 7.00pm The first day of the conference presents da Vinci and the approach that he took to all of his lines of enquiries. It analyses how da Vinci not only understood the essence of ‘systems’ thinking, but how he also applied this to his inventions, ideas and work generally. We ask, was this approach extraordinary for its time? Was da Vinci different from his renowned contemporaries in this way? To address these questions, the keynote speaker, Professor Galluzzi will present an overview of da Vinci’s life, influences, influencers and projects in this context, and Professor Fiorani will explore the educational context of da Vinci’s time and place. We will explore if there was something within the context of da Vinci’s time which encouraged his thinking and ‘systems’ awareness, or was this a one-off – a spike in the linear progression of epistemology? We ask if there are there other examples of interdisciplinary thinking and approaches throughout history. The day will continue with a reflection on the more recent times and the advent of new media – a marriage of two seemingly quite separate, established disciplines: art and technology, moving the dialogue into the 20th century, and beyond. Saturday, 9 May 2015 10:00am - 7.00pm The whistle-stop tour through key ‘systems thinkers’ in history from the previous day, which ended with a look at innovation today in Singapore, continues with a day exploring contemporary ‘systems approaches’, specifically addressing the areas of: education and pedagogical methodologies today; and how science and technology can be applied broadly to work through some of the world’s most pressing issues. Fittingly, the last session looks to the future, and how ‘systems thinking’ is being successfully used to address environmental issues – perhaps the biggest threat to the continuing survival of the planet and its inhabitants. And where is Singapore within this landscape? Confirmed participants include: Paolo Galluzzi (Italy) Alberto Rocca (Italy) David Harvey (USA) Gunalan Nadarajan (Singapore/USA) Luciano Chessa (Italy/USA) Ruben De La Nuez (Singapore) Vibeke Sorensen (Singapore) Justin Pickard (UK) Noorlinah Mohamed (Singapore) Forum for the Future More speakers to be announced.
events.location: ArtScience Museum

events.name: Null Singapore Humla - Write your own burp suite plugins
events.description:
Note: This is a free but an invite only event. If you are selected you will receive venue and other information via e-mail. (Laptop is mandatory for participation) 
 
What is null Humla ?  
Null Humla is a hands on workshop where attendees get to get their hands dirty with red team tools and usually held for 3-4 hours. The humla champion will be helping you in understanding and applying the content to real world scenarios.  
  
Humla Champion: Mohammed A Imran 
About Humla Champion - Mohammed A Imran aka secfigo is senior software security engineer at Autodesk and specializes in vulnerability assessment, penetration testing and static code analysis(SAST). He loves to build infosec communities, share his knowledge with the community  and has organized around 60+ secuirty events for the best null chapter, null hyderabad in India. He now leads null Singapore chapter. 
When not at work, he likes to practise his design skills and fiddle with development frameworks. 
  
Details of the workshop: 
1) Introduction to Burp Extender API 
2) Problems with Jython coercion 
3) Hello world Burp plugin 
4) Build, modify and send HTTP requests and retrieve responses 
5) Hows ProxyListener, HTTPListener different   
6) Automate manual efforts while doing assessments 
           - e.g., Automate the process of modifying the signed requests 
7) Work on any specific scenarios which you want to automate.  
   
Prerequisites: 
Knowledge: Fundamentals of OOPS concepts, basic python skills and some experience with burp suite. 
Hardware: Any dual core machine with 4 GB RAM, minimum 20 GB free space. 
Software: Windows 7 x64/ Any Linux Variant , Java 64 bit, Python 2.7 and Jython Standalone, Burp suite professional or Free version. 
Editor : Notepad++ (preferred) or any editor of your choice ( VIM or emacs anyone ;) )  
  
Useful Links: 
We will use windows as our development platform but any platform should do.  
  
Burp suite - http://portswigger.net/burp/download.htmlJython - 
Jython standalone 2.7rc2 version  - http://www.jython.org/downloads.html  
Python 2.7 - https://www.python.org/downloads/release/python-279/  
Vmware Player for running Samurai or WTE images - https://my.vmware.com/web/vmware/free#desktop_end_user_computing/vmware_player/7_0  
  
Please reach out to me at morpheus@null.co.in or @secfigo if you have any questions regarding the event.
events.location: TBD, , selected individuals will be informed of thevenue, Singapore null

events.name: Security - Addressing Challenges in IoT/IoE Applications
events.description: #AllThingsConnected The number of devices connected is estimated to be approximately 30B globally by 2020. One of the hottest topics in IoT/IoE application and solution design is how effectively the security challenges are addressed. Security has been highlighted as one of the top most challenges in almost all the surveys and feedbacks conducted. ATCAlliance and IITAAS-eCell are inviting you again for an expert professional talk, in the series on IoT/IoE. Security - Addressing Challenges in Internet of Things/ Internet of Everything Applications RadhaKrishna Hiremane (Regional Director, Data Center and IoT Product Marketing, Asia Pacific and Japan at Intel Corp) RK Hiremane manages Intel’s regional product marketing for Datacenter and IoT business for Asia-Pacific and Japan (APJ). Leading a team of 20+ across 7 countries at APJ, in his current role, he is responsible for managing regional revenue growth, enterprise software and cloud provider co-marketing, and product marketing activities for Enterprise Servers and Clients, Cloud, Big Data/Analytics, Telco, Channel, and IoT segments. “ Security is the key underlying capability that should span across end-to-end IoT infrastructure, meaning all the gateways that collect data from smart devices or sensors; including telco infrastructures that transfer data, cloud and data centres where data is stored and analysed, devices that connect to data centres to view the analysed data, as well as API infrastructure that enables app connectivity to a data centre.”-RadhaKrishna (Intel Corp) This is a paid event just to cover the nominal expenses for coffee! Pay while registering. REGISTER HERE: http://iitaas.org/item/967259 WHEN: 13th May’15: 6:00pm-8:30pm • 6:00- 7:00pm- Networking, Coffee & Introduction • 7:00- 7:30pm- Professional Talk • 7:30- 7:45pm- Break & Q & A • 7:45- 8:15pm- Professional Talk Contd. • 8:15- 8:35pm- QnA, Open Floor WHERE: iDA Labs@NDC National Design Centre111 Middle Road #03-04, Singapore[masked] Location Map We had a great response in our last professional talk by Dr Archan Misra on "SmartCity" (with 100+ Signups, and housefull! - Few pics here ). Could you now imagine the #CrowdSensing in your daily life? Now join us on 13th May to understand the Security challanges and solutions too! REGISTER HERE: http://iitaas.org/item/967259 Thanks, ATCAlliance Facebook | Twitter | LinkedIn | Meetup Note: Please note that photography and videography will be carried out throughout the event. ATCAlliance, IITAAS may use some or all of these images in its print publications, digital, social platforms and/or marketing channels.
events.location: iDA Labs @National Design Centre, 111 Middle Road, #03-04, Singapore 188969

events.name: Data Mining with R (Workshop I)
events.description: Hello everyone, At RUGS, we would like to encourage more people to use R, and to use R to do good statistics. As such, Alex and I are organising a series of tutorials on the top data mining algorithms. The content of the talks will aim to cover a little understanding of the theory, but will mostly focus on examples with R. The 8 - 10 algorithms we aim to cover include: • k-means • SVM • Apriori • Naive Bayes • Random forests and decision/regression trees • EM • kNN • AdaBoost We intend for the sessions to be held on a monthly basis, lasting about an hour or so. The venue will be 237 South Bridge Road. We’ll have to collect SGD 5 a head, but this goes toward the venue and refreshments (not into our pockets =)). We'll collect it at the door on the day itself. The speakers for the talks will be our very own RUGS members. If you are an expert in one of the topics and would like to conduct the session, do let us know! For the first talk, Alex will be speaking about SVM. Here is a short overview of the talk, and a little bit about Alex too About SVM: SVM is nowadays one of the most popular classification algorithms. It is efficient in dealing big data set. It allows us to fit nonlinear classification boundary with kernel methods. Moreover, the combination of penalization and “customized” kernel enable us to introduce prior knowledge into classification. In this R share session, we will quickly go through the theoretical part of SVM, and demonstrate the application with R package “kernlab”. And last but not least, we will show 2 examples to let you feel the power of SVM. About Alex: I am a statistician in HSOR@NHG. I have been studying statistics for 6 years and using R for 6 years. My research areas are statistical learning, computing statistics, data visualization and data science with population health management.
events.location: 237 (http://237.io/), 237 South Bridge Road Singapore 058786

events.name: PowerShell Forum
events.description: Full details soon! This is a 2 full day event with International Speakers as a build up to the PowerShell Summit 2016. It's the first event of its kind in Asia. This will have a nominal entrance fee (to help cover the huge costs) but there will be great intermediate and advanced content by MVPs and world recognised Experts. Registration will be via a different channel and will open nearer the time but we want to make sure this is in our User Groups schedule on Meet Up also.
